contentrichtext.text: The '''Keldysh Institute of Applied Mathematics''' ({{lang-ru|Институт прикладной математики им. М.В.Келдыша}}) of the [[Russian Academy of Sciences]] is a research institute specializing in [[computation]]al [[mathematics]]. The institute is located in [[Moscow]], [[Russia]]. It is named after [[Mstislav Keldysh]]. The institute was created in 1966 when it split from [[Steklov Institute of Mathematics]]. Already as the Department of Applied Mathematics of Steklov Institute it had conducted some outstanding research in the field of space exploration: in 1953 it developed the method of ballistic [[spacecraft]] descent, that was used on April 12, 1961 for [[Yuri Gagarin]]'s return to the Earth, and in 1957 [[Sputnik 1]] orbit was calculated there using the [[computer]] processing of [[observation|optical observation]] data.<ref>{{Ru icon}} [http://www.applmat.ru/pages/anniver/achievment/3_appl_mech.htm 50th anniversary of the Institute - Applied celestial mechanics]</ref> ==References== <references/> ==External links== * [http://www.keldysh.ru/ Institute web site] {{coord missing|Russia}} [[Category:Educational institutions established in 1966]] [[Category:Mathematical institutes]] [[Category:Research institutes in Russia]] [[Category:Universities and institutes established in the Soviet Union]] [[Category:Research institutes in the Soviet Union]] [[Category:Russian Academy of Sciences]] [[Category:1966 establishments in the Soviet Union]] {{math-stub}}
